awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  MSB-ECA: Resolving controls on lignin decomposition at the continental scale to reconcile classical and modern paradigms of soil organic matter
awd_abstract_narration:
Lignin is an important component of plant tissues that provides protection from herbivores and pathogens due to its complex chemical structure. When plant tissues die and enter the soil, lignin is often among the last components to decompose and may persist for decades or even longer. Despite the generally slow decay rates of lignin, recent work has suggested that many soils contain very little lignin in their organic matter. This apparent contradiction presents a key challenge for our understanding of soil organic matter formation, a topic which is critically linked to environmental services including soil fertility, water quality, and carbon storage. This research seeks to understand the environmental factors that control lignin decay rates and the ultimate contributions of lignin to soil organic matter in ecosystems across North America. The influence of differences in soil microorganisms and minerals on lignin decomposition across diverse ecosystems will be assessed. The broader implications of the findings for ecosystem functions and services will be studied by using a mathematical model. A postdoctoral researcher and graduate students will be trained, and findings will be communicated to the public and to land managers with targeted outreach activities.

This research seeks to resolve lingering inconsistencies in soil organic matter, where the context-specific importance of lignin may have been neglected due to spatial and methodological sampling biases. Interactions among lignin, soil geochemical characteristics, and microbial community composition may have significant impacts on lignin residence times and mineral sorption that emerge only when examined across continental-scale environmental gradients. Data collected from National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) sites will be combined with new experiments to test two hypotheses: (1) Does lignin decomposition rates and its abundance in soil organic matter predictably vary with soil geochemical characteristics and microbial community composition at the continental scale (in contrast to both classical and modern paradigms of soil organic matter)?; and (2) Can the representations of lignin decomposition and carbon cycling in a state-of-the-art mechanistic ecosystem model be improved by inclusion of geochemical and microbial parameters (in addition to the traditional variables of climate, residue quality, and nutrient availability)?  The NEON data will be combined with field and laboratory incubations of carbon isotope-labeled lignins and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopic measurements to test these hypotheses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Lignin is a very abundant molecule in nature. It provides structure and protection to plant tissues, and it often decomposes more slowly than other parts of leaves and wood. Nevertheless, the fate of lignin in soils remains poorly understood. Because of its comparatively slow decay, lignin was long thought to be a major component of soil organic matter, but recent research challenged this assumption. Resolving the fates of lignin in soil is important for understanding the composition, abundance, and spatial distribution of soil organic matter, and the numerous ecosystem services that soil organic matter provides (e.g., food and fiber production, water availability, carbon sequestration), as well as for predicting future changes in soil organic matter due to climate or management change. We used samples and data from the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) to test factors that influence lignin decomposition and abundance, and their relationships with soil organic carbon, using laboratory and field experiments and mechanistic modeling.

We found that differences in soil chemistry and microbial communities could predict large differences in lignin content and decomposition rate among diverse North American soils.The contribution of lignin to soil organic matter was not consistently large or small, but varied predictably with soil biogeochemical factors, some of which were ultimately related to climate. Moreover, the key variables that shaped lignin and litter decomposition rates often differed from those that controlled bulk soil organic matter decomposition, or they had opposite relationships. However, the factors that best predicted the abundance of lignin in soil organic matter were also strong predictors of total soil organic carbon content, highlighting the important contributions of lignin to total soil carbon in certain environments.

These results have important implications for carbon cycle models used to predict climate change, which generally do not track the fate of lignin during decomposition. Indeed, we found that including an explicit representation of lignin in the Dynamic Land Ecosystem Model greatly improved the overall predictions of soil carbon cycling relative to the original model. Consistent with our experiments, the model was able to reproduce different temporal patterns of lignin and litter decomposition within and among soils by accounting for their chemical and microbial differences.

During the project period, we disseminated our findings by publishing six peer-reviewed publications in highly regarded scientific journals, with two more papers in review. Data from these studies was published online for further use by the scientific community, thereby benefitting future researchers, especially the NEON user community. Our team also delivered several presentations on this work at scientific conferences. We communicated general findings of our soil organic matter research through an NSF-funded Portal to the Public program at a local botanical garden and through webinars targeted to farmers and land managers. Three PhD students and one postdoctoral scholar were trained through this project, and six undergraduate students received research mentorship, including four students from backgrounds that are underrepresented in STEM.
